'''Doris Hart''' (June 20, 1925 – May 29, 2015) was a [[tennis]] player from the United States who was active in the 1940s and first half of the 1950s. She was ranked world No. 1 in 1951. She was the fourth player, and second woman, to win a Career Grand Slam in singles. She was the first of only three players (all women) to complete the career "[[Grand Slam (tennis)#Boxed Set|Boxed Set]]" of [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] titles, which is winning at least one title in singles, women's doubles, and mixed doubles at all four Grand Slam events. Only [[Margaret Court|Margaret Smith Court]] and she achieved this during the amateur era of the sport.

==Tennis career==
Hart reached 67 [[Grand Slam in tennis|Grand Slam]] finals and won 35  titles, tying with [[Louise Brough]] for sixth on the all-time list (behind [[Margaret Court|Margaret Smith Court]] (64), [[Martina Navratilova]] (59), [[Billie Jean King]] (39), [[Serena Williams]] (39), and [[Margaret Osborne duPont]] (37)). Six of her titles were in women's singles, 14 in women's doubles, and 15 in mixed doubles.<ref name="nyt">{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/01/sports/tennis/doris-hart-tennis-standout-despite-physical-limitations-dies-at-89.html?_r=0 | title=Doris Hart, Tennis Standout Despite Physical Limitations, Dies at 89 | work=The New York Times | date=May 31, 2015 | accessdate=May 31, 2015 | author=Frank Litsky}}</ref> Hart is one of only three players, all women, to have a "boxed set" of Grand Slam titles — every possible title (singles, women's doubles, and mixed doubles) from all four Grand Slam tournaments. The others are Margaret Smith Court and Martina Navratilova.<ref name="nyt"/> Hart was  the first person to accomplish this feat.<ref name="globe">{{cite web | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/grand-slam-tennis-champ-doris-hart-of-us-dies-at-89/article24714099/ | archive-url=https://archive.is/20150531103509/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/grand-slam-tennis-champ-doris-hart-of-us-dies-at-89/article24714099/ | title=Grand Slam tennis champ Doris Hart of U.S. dies at 89 | work=The Globe and Mail | author=Reuters | date=May 30, 2015 | accessdate=June 1, 2015 | url-status=dead | archive-date=May 31, 2015}}</ref>

As a child, Hart suffered from [[osteomyelitis]], which resulted in a permanently impaired right leg. She started playing tennis when she was 10 years old, greatly encouraged by her brother Bud.<ref name="nyt"/>

After losing seven Grand Slam finals from 1942 through 1946, Hart won her first Grand Slam title at the [[1947 Wimbledon Championships]] in [[1947 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles|women's doubles]]. At that point, she was still a student at the [[University of Miami (Florida)|University of Miami]].<ref name="guardian">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/may/31/doris-hart | title=Doris Hart obituary | author=Richard Evans | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | location=London | date=May 31, 2015 | accessdate=June 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FeD7AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA56 | title=Legendary Locals of Greater Miami | author=Howard Kleinberg | publisher=Arcadia Publishing | year=2013 | page=56}}</ref>

Her first Grand Slam singles title came at the [[1949 Australian Championships|1949 Australian National Championships]], where she was the only non-Australian player in the [[1949 Australian Championships – Women's Singles|draw]]. She also won singles titles at the [[1950 French Championships (tennis)|1950]] and [[1952 French Championships (tennis)|1952 French International Championships]], the [[1951 Wimbledon Championships]] (routing doubles partner [[Shirley Fry]] in the final)<ref name="guardian"/>, and the [[1954 U.S. National Championships (tennis)|1954]] and [[1955 U.S. National Championships (tennis)|1955 U. S. National Championships]].<ref name="guardian"/><ref name="abc">{{cite web | url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/tennis-career-grand-slam-winner-doris-hart-dies-31416048 | title=Tennis Career Grand Slam Winner Doris Hart Dies at 89 | work=ABC News | date=May 30, 2015 | accessdate=June 1, 2015 | author=Associated Press}}</ref> The 1955 U. S. singles final was the last Grand Slam singles match of her career.<ref name="abc"/> 

Hart won the [[1951 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles|singles]], [[1951 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles|women's doubles]], and [[1951 Wimbledon Championships – Mixed Doubles|mixed doubles]] titles at the 1951 Wimbledon Championships, playing the finals of all three events on the same day (July 7, 1951).<ref name="guardian"/> She also won the "triple crown" at the 1952 French International Championships and the 1954 U. S. National Championships.<ref name="TelegObit">{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11643656/Doris-Hart-tennis-champion-obituary.html | title=Doris Hart, tennis champion – obituary | work=The Daily Telegraph | date=June 1, 2015 | accessdate=June 1, 2015}}</ref>

During her [[Wightman Cup]] career from 1946 through 1955, Hart was a perfect 14–0 in singles matches and 8–1 in doubles matches.<ref name="nyt"/>

Hart did not lose a Grand Slam women's doubles match from the [[1951 French Championships (tennis)|1951 French International Championships]] through the semifinals of the [[1954 Wimbledon Championships]], 43 matches in total, although she skipped 4 Grand Slam tournaments during this period. She also did not lose a mixed doubles match at the 13 Grand Slam tournaments she played from the 1951 French International Championships through the 1955 U. S. National Championships. She (and partner [[Stan Smith]]) finally lost in the [[1968 Wimbledon Championships – Mixed Doubles|third round]] of the [[1968 Wimbledon Championships]] to [[Frew McMillan]] and [[Annette Van Zyl|Annette Van Zyl Du Plooy]] 6-3, 12-10.

According to John Olliff and Lance Tingay of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' and the ''[[Daily Mail]]'', Hart was ranked in the world top ten from 1946 through 1955 (no rankings issued from 1940 through 1945), reaching a career high of World No. 1 in those rankings in 1951.<ref>{{cite book |author=Collins, Bud |title=The Bud Collins History of Tennis: An Authoritative Encyclopedia and Record Book |publisher=New Chapter Press |location=New York City |year=2008 |pages=695, 702–3 |isbn=0-942257-41-3}}</ref> Hart was included in the year-end top ten rankings issued by the [[United States Tennis Association|United States Lawn Tennis Association]] from 1942 through 1955. She was the top ranked U. S. player in 1954 and 1955.<ref>{{cite book |author=United States Tennis Association |title=1988 Official USTA Tennis Yearbook |publisher=H. O. Zimman, Inc. |location=Lynn, Massachusetts |year=1988 |pages=260–1}}</ref>

Hart retired from the tour in late 1955 to become a tennis teaching professional. Her autobiography, ''Tennis with Hart'', was published that year.<ref name="TelegObit"/>

She was inducted into the [[International Tennis Hall of Fame]] in 1969.

She died on May 29, 2015, at her home in [[Coral Gables, Florida]], aged 89.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.si.com/tennis/2015/05/30/ap-ten-obit-doris-hart-1st-ld-writethru | title=Tennis career Grand Slam winner Doris Hart dies at 89 | work=Sports Illustrated |date=May 30, 2015 | accessdate=May 30, 2015}}</ref>
